text:
Probably the worst Rare game on the N64. Banjo Kazooie was pushing the boundaries, but DK64 just had far too much collecting to do.

The music was solid, as always, though it's also arguably the weakest among Rare N64 games.

text: I loved this game as a kid. It's not as good as the banjo kazooie games, but i loved the music and levels WAY more then mario 64. UNFORTUNATELY, the game's so much of a collectathon, that i will probably never beat the game 100%. Heck, i never beat the game. BUT i did at least beat the game up to right before the final level(i lacked the final 2 keys and the blue prints to get into the final level). Maybe one day i'll finish it, in the mean time i'll listen to it's AWESOME music.

author: j

text:
Maybe it's because I've never played this myself, but I did watch a Let's Play of this game. I liked some of the earlier areas of the game, and I liked the music for Crystal Caves

But near the end, the collectathon-nature of the game kind of became very repetitive, and made me realize DK64 was just "Collectathon The Game" with mini-games after mini-games. I'm sure I'd get a different impression if I play the game myself. As SupraDarky said, in a world where I have too much time on my hands, I'd be down to check it out. But alas.

author: EvilMariobot

text: Beaver Bother notwithstanding, I never thought the minigames were TOO terrible. I will agree getting 101% is indeed a time sink. (even with a guide) My big wall in the game was trying to beat Donkey Kong Arcade a second time to get the Nintendo Coin and access the last Key.
author: EvilMariobot

text: @SupraDarky I played it back when it was released, but didn't get to finish it. Was a decent Mario64/Banjo-like platformer, and had a nice soundtrack, besides it being really cool to see Donkey Kong's character graphics realized in full above-average-n64-3D. But it was WAY. TOO. F-ING. LONG! They did manage to put so much padding in the game to make it get old. At least for a semi-completionist such as myself.
author: Claudio Marcelo Basckeira

text: @SupraDarky Really? You weren't a fan of this game? Well I guess everyone has their own opinion.
author: Joey Ford

text:
@SupraDarky I´m very surprised to learn, from the above comments and from general hearsay, that a lot of people seemingly didn´t like DK64. I got it as a kid when it came out, and I have nothing but good things to say about it. It´s extremely atmospheric, it´s got good level design, and the gameplay is all over the place with the different characters and mini games (out of which the roller coaster ones stick out as exceptionally fun, to me anyway) . Even the bosses were clever and very memorable.
One thing I hear often from people who claim to dislike DK64 (they tend to be people who also didn´t actually play it, strangely enough) is that "It´s got glitches", to which I can only think: "Yeah? Nearly every great game had glitches, but it´s not something that the average player would likely encounter, for the most part. OoT had glitches - is OoT bad?"
author: steaktastebetterpill

text: @steaktastebetterpill The main problem people have with DK64 is that there's too many things to collect. I personally don't mind it, it just means players are challenged to memorize the maps more accurately than in other games (and some later worlds do get pretty maze-y, like the caves), but if you don't want to invest your time in the game because of that, that's fine by me.
author: Hawlo

text: @Dom'sDominatingGaming Cool that you noticed! I don´t get a lot of comments on that!
author: steaktastebetterpill

text: @***** At least it's not as boring as Mario is Missing or Call of Duty. Just saying.
author: Joey Ford

text:
@*****
I find Donkey Kong 64 to be as good as the Banjo-Kazooie games on N64. IMHO
